title: Joe Ansbro
text:
Joe Ansbro (Born <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, 29 October 1985) is a former Scottish international professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. He is the first player of African origin to represent Scotland at test level in history. His favoured position is <a href="centre%20%28rugby%20union%29">centre</a>. He most recently played for <a href="London%20Irish">London Irish</a>. After gaining 11 full international caps his rugby career ended due to serious neck injury at the age of 26.
Early years.
Ansbro was born in Glasgow and raised near <a href="Gatehouse%20of%20Fleet">Gatehouse of Fleet</a> in <a href="Dumfries%20%26amp%3B%20Galloway">Dumfries & Galloway</a>, South West Scotland. He was educated at Gatehouse Primary School and played youth rugby with Stewartry, the <a href="Castle%20Douglas">Castle Douglas</a> club. He was also educated at <a href="Stonyhurst%20College">Stonyhurst College</a> near <a href="Clitheroe">Clitheroe</a> in <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, North West England, before embarking on study of a Natural Sciences degree at <a href="Robinson%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Robinson College, Cambridge</a>.
Northampton.
Ansbro joined the Northampton Academy in 2006, during this time he was part of the <a href="Cambridge%20University%20R.F.C.">Cambridge University</a> side that took part in <a href="The%20Varsity%20Match">The Varsity Match</a>, producing some quality displays for the <a href="University">University</a>. <a href="Northampton%20Saints">Northampton Saints</a> took notice of this and he became a regular in the number 13 shirt during their season in <a href="National%20Division%20One">National Division One</a>, he also scored in the <a href="EDF%20Energy%20Trophy">EDF Energy Trophy</a> final.
London Irish.
Ansbro joined <a href="London%20Irish">London Irish</a> in 2011 on a three-year deal. The Scotland centre was one of numerous international players to join the club in 2011. London Irish head coach Toby Booth said: "He's quick, powerful with a great future ahead and will fit in nicely." Ansbro commented that "there are some great players who have committed their long term futures to the club and that speaks volumes for what is happening there."
Scotland.
Ansbro made his international debut for <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland A</a> during the 2009 <a href="IRB%20Nations%20Cup">IRB Nations Cup</a> tournament in Romania. <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland A</a> eventually went on to win the tournament, with Ansbro making his debut as outside centre in the win against Uruguay. 
He made his first senior Scotland appearance in the 21–17 victory over reigning world champions <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> in doing so he became the first black player to represent Scotland at test level. A week later he played in the 19–16 win against Samoa at <a href="Pittodrie">Pittodrie</a> in Aberdeen.
Ansbro made his <a href="Six%20Nations%20Championship">6 nations</a> appearance in <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a>'s opening match of the <a href="2011%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2011 Six Nations Championship</a> against France in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>. Ansbro and the rest of the <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> team put in an impressive performance against a clinical French side despite eventually losing the match 34–21.
His first points for <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> came in the 10–6 victory in a <a href="2011%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2011 Rugby World Cup</a> warm-up game against <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a> where he scored the winning try in the 76th minute. Ansbro was included in Scotland's 30 man squad for the <a href="2011%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2011 Rugby World Cup</a> in New Zealand. He went on to score his first RWC try against <a href="Romania%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Romania</a> in Scotland's first group game of the 2011 tournament. The number 13 jersey in the next two games was taken by <a href="Nick%20de%20Luca">Nick de Luca</a> before Ansbro was again selected, this time in Scotland's final group game versus England.
Injury.
Ansbro broke his neck in a pre-season friendly against <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a> on 24 August 2012. After being taken to hospital straight after the match it was discovered that Ansbro had a triple fracture of the C1 vertebrae. As of 15 May 2013 Ansbro officially retired from rugby union.
Teaching.
Ansbro, having graduated from <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a> before his professional career became a Biology teacher and rugby coach at <a href="Harrow%20School">Harrow School</a>, a leading boys' independent school.
